Investigation 3

Scaling Perimeter and Area

In Shapes and Designs, we learned that some polygons fit together to cover, or tile, a flat surface. For example, the surface of a honeycomb has a pattern of regular hexagons. Many bathroom and kitchen floors are covered with a pattern of square tiles. These patterns of polygons that fit together are called tessellations.

Look closely at the pattern of squares. The large square is similar to each of the nine small squares. The large square has sides formed by the sides of three small squares, so the scale factor from the small square to the large square is 3.

tiles.title: Similar squares with a scale factor of 3 or 1/3

text: We can also put four small squares together to make a four-tile square. This four-tile square is similar to both the large nine-tile square and the small single-tile square.

tiles.title: Similar squares with a scale factor of 2 or 1/2

text: No matter how closely we look at the hexagon pattern, however, we cannot find a large hexagon made up of similar smaller hexagons.

A shape is a rep-tile if you can put together copies that are the same size and shape (congruent) to make a larger shape that is similar to one of the copies. The copies may be rotated to fit together. A square is a rep-tile. A hexagon is not a rep-tile.
